title: Dry Skin
author: Felicia Wilson

sections.heading: What Is Dry Skin?
content: Dry skin is when your skin dries out because it doesn’t have enough moisture. It isn’t usually serious, but it can be irritating. If you have severe dry skin, you should see a doctor.
Eczema can look different on different skin tones. (Photo credit: Puntasit Choksawatdikorn/Dreamstime)
There are many causes of dry skin, from the temperature outside to how much moisture is in the air .

sections.heading: Types of Dry Skin
content: Although dry skin is usually temporary, there are types of dry skin that could last year-round. If your dry skin lasts a long time, it could be one of these types:
Athlete’s foot. If your feet feel dry, it could actually be athlete’s foot. This condition, which results from a fungus , can make the soles of your feet dry and flaky.

Contact dermatitis. Sometimes, things that touch your skin can cause an allergic reaction . Your skin could get dry, itchy, and red. You might also get a rash . It can happen with things such as makeup products, medications , detergents, or metal in jewelry (nickel).

sections.heading: Eczema
content: ( atopic dermatitis ). If your skin has dry, red, and itchy parts, you could have eczema. This can also make your skin crack. You can get this skin condition from your parents, but things such as allergens, stress , and other irritants can make it worse.

Seborrheic dermatitis. When your scalp is too dry, you can get dandruff . (It’s called cradle cap when babies get it.) You might have dry, flaky skin on your arms, legs, groin, face, ears , or near your belly button.

sections.heading: Dry Skin Symptoms
content: Dry skin can be different for each person, as the symptoms depend on factors such as your health, your age, and the cause of your dry skin. But chances are, when you have dry skin, you’ll have symptoms such as:
bullets: Cracked skin (the cracks could be deep and bleed)
Itching
Peeling, flaking, or scaling
Redness
Skin that feels rough or is gray and ashy
Skin that feels tight, especially after you’ve been in the water (bathing, showering, or swimming )

sections.heading: What Causes Dry Skin?
content: Usually, dry skin happens because of environmental factors, such as the weather. Dry skin can be caused by:

content_blocks.text: Usually, dry skin happens because of environmental factors, such as the weather. Dry skin can be caused by:

sections.heading: Harsh detergents or soaps.
content: Soaps, shampoos, and detergents are made to get rid of oil on your skin. That means they can also dry it out by removing all the moisture.
Heat. Any heat source, from space heaters and central heating to fireplaces and wood stoves, can lower the humidity in a room and make your skin dry.
Hot showers or baths. Taking long, hot showers or soaking in a hot bath could cause dry skin.
Other skin conditions. People with certain conditions, such as psoriasis or eczema, can also get dry skin.
Swimming in pools. Chlorine, a chemical that keeps some pools clean, can dry out your skin.
Weather. During the winter, humidity and temperature usually drop. This can make your skin drier.
Although dry skin is common and can affect anyone, there are some things that make you more likely to get it. Your chances of getting dry skin can depend on:

sections.heading: Your age.
content: If you’re 40 or older, your chances are higher. Over 50% of older adults have dry skin.
Where you live. Your odds go up if you live in cold or dry climates without much humidity.
Your job. If your skin gets wet often during your job, it’s more likely to dry out. Swimming instructors and hairstylists often have their skin in water.

Your health conditions and genes. Some people inherit from their parents some health conditions that can cause dry skin. These include eczema, diabetes , kidney disease , thyroid, and other hormone disorders.

sections.heading: Other Dry Skin Causes and Inflammation
content: So, what causes your skin to break out in red, itchy patches? Experts aren’t exactly sure. But research says things such as health, genetics, environment, certain products, and lifestyle may act as triggers. But eczema affects different people in different ways, so the things that cause you to have flare-ups may not bother someone else.

Immune system . You may have eczema because your body has an immune system that reacts too much. It responds easily to something that’s either inside your body (such as genes) or outside of it (such as an allergen or irritant). This reaction damages the skin barrier — the topmost layer of your skin that defends your body from bacteria and keeps it from losing too much moisture. Without this protection, your skin is more sensitive, dry, brittle, and prone to inflammation .

sections.heading: Genetics.
content: You’re more likely to have eczema if you have:

Research shows that you’re also more likely to have eczema if you have a gene mutation that makes your body less able to produce enough filaggrin. This is a type of protein that helps your body build a strong skin barrier. If you’re low on filaggrin, your skin may lose a lot of water and become dry. It can also expose your skin to viruses and bacteria and make it more prone to infection.
There’s no cure or supplement you can take to fix your filaggrin levels, but keeping your immune system healthy can help ward off skin problems.
Environment. A change in weather, seasons, and temperature can cause your eczema to flare up.

In the winter, dry air can suck the moisture from your skin and cause itching. This can make your eczema worse. When you turn up the heat to make your house warm, this can dry your skin out and irritate it.

Asthma
Hay fever
Allergy to environmental factors such as pollen , poison ivy , or pet hair
Food allergy

In the winter, dry air can suck the moisture from your skin and cause itching. This can make your eczema worse. When you turn up the heat to make your house warm, this can dry your skin out and irritate it.

content: During summer, because of high temperatures, you may lose water from your skin if you don’t take in more fluids. This can lead to dryness and cause your eczema to flare up. Hot weather also makes your body sweat more and lose water as a way to cool your body.

Besides water, sweat is also made up of certain metals, such as zinc, copper, and iron. When these come in contact with your skin, they can irritate it and set off a reaction. The sweat tends to build up most in the creases of your elbows, the backs of your knees, and the neck. These then become “hot spots” for eczema rashes .
The heat itself can also trigger your eczema. Hot weather tends to expand your blood vessels underneath the skin and cause inflamed cells to move. This can kick-start the itching and burning.

Allergens and irritants. Many of the daily products you use at home, work, or on your body may irritate your skin or cause an allergic reaction. Whether mild or severe, these things could make your eczema worse. They can cause a type of eczema called contact dermatitis.

sections.heading: Dry Skin Treatment and Prevention
content: When it comes to household skin irritants, the list is practically endless. It includes cleaning products, floor polishes, air fresheners, and laundry detergent, just to name a few. These products strip skin of water and oils it needs, leading to dryness and irritation. For some people, dry skin can progress to more serious conditions, such as eczema or dermatitis .

It includes cleaning products, floor polishes, air fresheners, and laundry detergent, just to name a few. These products strip skin of water and oils it needs, leading to dryness and irritation. For some people, dry skin can progress to more serious conditions, such as eczema or dermatitis .

content: The following measures can make things easier on your skin:
Wear gloves for housework

To take good care of your hands, you need to protect them from harsh household cleaners and dish detergents, which are proven skin irritants. Use non-latex rubber gloves when it’s time to scrub. Or better yet, create a double barrier of protection: Wear a pair of rubber gloves over a layer of thin, soft cotton ones before you touch a bucket or sponge.
Shower and moisturize after a swim

Using chlorine to keep your pool clean can also dry your skin out. The best treatment: As soon as you or your children step out of the pool, head inside to rinse off with water and mild soap. Follow up with a moisturizer that lists glycerin as the first ingredient. It will help your skin hold on to moisture and prevent future dryness.

content_blocks.text: Stress. Experts say that if you’re feeling emotional distress, it could set off an eczema breakout or make it worse. But they’re not sure why that happens. If you have severe eczema, the intense itching, pain, and burning could make it hard to relax or fall asleep, cause anxiety and depression, or make you feel self-conscious about how the dry, scaly patches look. This can cause you stress and lower your quality of life.

sections.heading: Dry Skin Treatment and Prevention
content: When it comes to household skin irritants, the list is practically endless. It includes cleaning products, floor polishes, air fresheners, and laundry detergent, just to name a few. These products strip skin of water and oils it needs, leading to dryness and irritation. For some people, dry skin can progress to more serious conditions, such as eczema or dermatitis .

content: The following measures can make things easier on your skin:
Wear gloves for housework

To take good care of your hands, you need to protect them from harsh household cleaners and dish detergents, which are proven skin irritants. Use non-latex rubber gloves when it’s time to scrub. Or better yet, create a double barrier of protection: Wear a pair of rubber gloves over a layer of thin, soft cotton ones before you touch a bucket or sponge.
Shower and moisturize after a swim

Using chlorine to keep your pool clean can also dry your skin out. The best treatment: As soon as you or your children step out of the pool, head inside to rinse off with water and mild soap. Follow up with a moisturizer that lists glycerin as the first ingredient. It will help your skin hold on to moisture and prevent future dryness.

sections.heading: Try coconut oil
content: Because it has essential fatty acids ( EFAs ), coconut oil can help keep your skin hydrated and protected. Ask your doctor about adding it to your diet to help keep your skin moisturized. You can also use it as a moisturizer and rub it on your skin.

sections.heading: Slather on petroleum jelly
content: If you have sensitive skin that’s easily bothered by household skin irritants, the best treatments contain the fewest ingredients. When abrasive household products touch skin, they break down its protective barrier. Putting a chemical-laden moisturizer on top of an already weakened area leads to burning, stinging, itching, and redness.

Because it contains only one ingredient, petroleum jelly is gentle on your skin. You can use it to soothe dry skin, from your lips to your hands to your feet. Because it’s so safe and inexpensive, you can apply it as often as you like.
Take an oatmeal bath
Oats have been used to treat dry skin for centuries. But only recently have researchers found what eases the itch — chemicals called avenanthramides that fight inflammation and redness .

To make the most of oats’ itch-fighting power, toss them into lukewarm bathwater. Grind either quick or old-fashioned oatmeal in a blender or food processor, and slowly sprinkle it into the tub as the water runs. Then soak for at least 15 minutes.

sections.heading: Banish dust mites
content: One common household skin irritant lives and breathes in almost every room of your home: the dust mite. To prevent mite-related itch and irritated skin, vacuum floors and carpets, and wash your bedding in water that’s 130 F or hotter at least once a week.
Switch to hydrating hand sanitizer

You can’t check out at a convenience store or walk into a doctor’s office without seeing a hand sanitizer dispenser these days. And many families keep bottles all over the house for quick and easy hand cleansing.
But alcohol-based sanitizers can really dry out your hands. Look for hydrating versions that say dermatologist-recommended on the label.

If your skin is extremely dry and itchy or tends to crack, your doctor might prescribe a topical steroid to ease inflammation. Oral or injectable medications may be necessary if your condition is severe.

sections.heading: Foods for dry skin
content: Eating a balanced diet can help keep your skin healthy. But what if you have dry skin? Are there some foods that can help? Besides getting plenty of water for hydration, here are some foods that will help moisturize and hydrate your skin.
bullets: Beef liver (high in vitamin A, which boosts cell regeneration and helps your skin retain moisture)
Yellowfin tuna (has selenium, which protects your skin)
Sweet potatoes (high in vitamin C and increase your collagen)
Cucumbers (high water content, about 95% water)
Avocados (high in healthy fats, vitamin E, and biotin)
Yellow, orange, and red bell peppers (high in beta-carotene, which helps with dry and aging skin)
Nuts and seeds such as pumpkin and sunflower seeds, which are high in vitamin E and zinc, respectively
Oatmeal (can be eaten or applied on the skin; has emollient properties)
Green tea (helps keep your skin from drying out)
Coconut water (may help reduce skin dryness and slow aging)
Turmeric (has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties to soothe your skin)

sections.heading: Best Moisturizers for Dry Skin
content: When choosing a moisturizer for your dry skin, look for products that:
bullets: Don’t have fragrances
Don’t contain ingredients that dry your skin, such as isopropyl alcohol, benzyl alcohol, or sulfates
Include ingredients that lock in moisture, such as petroleum jelly, hyaluronic acid, lanolin, or mineral oils (emollients)
Include ingredients that attract moisture, such as glycerin
Stop itching (hydrocortisone steroid)
Protect your skin from the sun with an SPF
Are designed for the affected area of your skin (face vs. body). You may need more than one moisturizer for different parts of your body.

sections.heading: When to See a Dermatologist for Dry Skin
content: Sometimes, you can relieve dry skin by drinking more water, eating healthy foods, or using soaps, lotions, and skin care products. But if you’ve tried these and these aren't working, you may want some professional help.
Some of the reasons you may want to see a board-certified dermatologist include:
bullets: You have open sores or blisters from scratching.
You can’t sleep because of the constant itch.
You have large areas of peeling skin.
Your skin is painful to touch or inflamed.

sections.heading: Dry Skin FAQs
content: What vitamin deficiency causes dry skin?

There is no one vitamin deficiency that causes dry skin. Dermatologists suggest you take the following for healthy skin: vitamins A, C, D, E and B vitamins such as B3 (niacin). Also, consider adding omega-3 fatty acids, zinc, and collagen to your diet.
What to drink for dry skin?

Drink plenty of water and other drinks high in antioxidants, such as green tea, which can help boost collagen and elastin in your skin. But drink it in moderation because too much caffeine can be dehydrating.
How do I hydrate my skin?

From the inside, you can hydrate your skin by drinking plenty of water, fruit juices, and drinks such as green tea. In addition, you can also eat plenty of fruits and vegetables that have high antioxidant levels and water content, such as cucumbers and red, orange, and yellow bell peppers. On the outside, you can use a moisturizer several times a day, and avoid using harsh soaps and hot showers. You can also use a humidifier, if the air where you live is dry. If all else fails, you can go to your dermatologist for meds that can help.

sections.heading: Which vitamin is good for dry skin?
content: There are several vitamins that will help you with your dry skin. They include:
Other things, such as omega-3 fatty acids, zinc, and collagen, are also helpful.
Does drinking water help dry skin?

Drinking water will help your health overall, but dry skin is caused by water loss from the outer layer of your skin. To add moisture back into your skin, you can avoid using harsh soaps, limit taking hot showers and baths, and try using hydrating skin care products, especially those that will lock in moisture.
Which soap is best for dry skin?

Look for soaps that are gentle, fragrance-free, and allergen-free. Harsh soaps can dry out your skin. Use your deodorant soaps only in areas such as your armpits, genital areas, and feet. You can also use cream-based bars or cleansers. Moisturizing body washes may also help with dry skin.
